Directions
Preheat oven to 325°F. Line a small rimmed baking sheet with parchment. In a small bowl, stir together butter, brown sugar, 1 1/2 teaspoons of the honey, salt, cinnamon, and cardamom (if using) until smooth.
Serious Eats / Robby Lozano
If desired, trim crusts from bread to yield a perfectly square slice. Spread a thin layer of butter mixture over top, bottom, and sides of each bread slice. Place on prepared baking sheet.
Serious Eats / Robby Lozano
Bake until very lightly golden-brown, 12 to 16 minutes. Flip slices and continue to bake until evenly golden, 5 to 7 minutes longer.
Serious Eats / Robby Lozano
Remove from oven and cool on baking sheet for 5 minutes. Transfer to a wire rack and cool until crispy, about 10 minutes.
Serious Eats / Robby Lozano
While toast cools, whisk together yogurt and vanilla bean paste until smooth. Stir in remaining 1 teaspoon honey, maintaining a swirl by not completely stirring it in.
Serious Eats / Robby Lozano
Place crisped toast on a plate; dollop with yogurt, then spoon berries on top. Drizzle with more honey, if desired. Serve immediately.
Serious Eats / Robby Lozano. Food Stylist: Julia Levy, Prop Stylist: Tucker Vines
Special Equipment
Small rimmed baking sheet, parchment
Make Ahead and Storage
The butter mixture can be made up to 3 days ahead and stored at room temperature in an airtight container or refrigerated in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks. Let it come to room temperature before use for easier spreadability.
Bread can be slathered with the butter mixture and then refrigerated overnight for easier baking in the morning.
Toast is best the day it is baked.
